title: Nasa could grow tomatoes on Mars and it means weed farming may also be possible
text:
You’ve heard of the Red Planet – but will it soon be known as the Green Planet too?

Whenever you hear someone is cultivating ‘tomatoes’ you should probably be a little bit suspicious about what’s really growing in their greenhouse.

So when scientists confirmed that it’s possible to grow the lovely little fruity veggie things on the Red Planet, it can also be seen as confirmation that weed could survive there too.

Cannabis-growing equipment is often sold legally under the pretence it will be used to nourish a nice red crop of tomatoes, rather than a green skunk harvest.

And in one memorable case in 2015, an Irish man claimed to have no idea how his tomato plants suddenly started emitting a strange smell and sprouted huge buds of weed.

During the case, which was heard in 2015, Judge O’Connor said: ‘This is the matter where the tomato plants miraculously converted themselves into cannabis plants.’

‘With the aid of holy water,’ the accidental weed farmer’s lawyer replied.

An illegal cannabis farm discovered near the earthly city of Liverpool (Provider: Merseyside Police)

Which brings us to a study which suggested the afore-mentioned fruit could be grown on Mars along with garden cress, rocket, tomato, radish, rye, quinoa, chives, pea and leeks.

Researchers from the Wageningen University and Research in the Netherlands (where weed is decriminalised) managed to cultivate the legal crops in simulated Martian soil.

‘A human settlement on Mars or the Moon is becoming more realistic,’ said Dr Wieger Wamelink, lead author of the study.

‘Several countries and private companies are preparing for this journey.

“One of the major issues will be ensuring food availability and safety.”

‘Food can and will be brought along, but for a permanent stay, production of crops on Mars or the Moon to supplement or even supply the total food demand could be a necessity.’

Elon Musk is hoping to launch a mission to Mars (Image: YouTube)

The team used fake Mars soil created by Nasa, as well as simulated lunar soil, which was mixed with organic matter and ‘stimulant’ to help crops grow.

‘We were thrilled when we saw the first tomatoes ever grown on the Mars soil simulant turning red,’ Dr Wamelink added.

‘This means that the next step towards a sustainable closed agricultural ecosystem had been taken.’

It’s probably best that the scientists didn’t try to grow cannabis because life on Mars would be hard, lonely and monotonous.

A dose of weed paranoia could prove too much to bear for any astronaut living in the claustrophobic confines of a Martian space base.
